3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:28): hi!  How do you guys feel about Apple's <input type="search">?

3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:29): I see tons of sites using JS/CSS hacks to implement similar functionality; it seems like standardizing it should be helpful, and Apple already has a working implementation.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:35): 3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a: What exactly would you require of a user agent to conform?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:36): 3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a: and what problem does it solve?

78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (01:36): a while back lachlan & mpt also (briefly) made the case for <input type="search"> here: http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2007-May/011367.html
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:37): here's the details as I understand them:  https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=456229
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:38): likes <input type="search">
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:39): and also placeholder

3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:39): I've heard that the "placeholder" option is being added to all (relevant) input types (not just search); I'm not sure if that's an official HTML 5 thing or just something Mozilla is doing.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:39): which is separately useful even for non-search input types
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:39): WebKit has placeholder on all text-like input types
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:40): some of the <input type="search> stuff duplicates more general mechanisms in WF2
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:40): the autocomplete stuff?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:40): I would like to deprecate them when we add the relevant WF2 stuff but not sure we can ever remove
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:40): well incremental
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:40): and the event that results
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:40): that makes sense.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:40): would be oninput
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:40): ah okay
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:41): the main issue is, right now everybody is reinventing the wheel, and some implementations are better than others.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:42): Mozilla sounds like they are just copying what WebKit has
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:42): so I don't think there is reinvention exactly

3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:42): if there were a standard way to do it in HTML, that everybody could use, then they'd just use that, and either use JS to fake compatibility with old browsers (same as they're doing now), or let old browsers have reduced functionality if that's easier.
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:43): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: that Mozilla bug was something I recently submitted, when I couldn't find an existing one.
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:43): I attempted to describe Apple's implementation, but that doesn't mean Mozilla is actually doing it.
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:43): I think they did say placeholder will be supported soon though.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:44): 3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a: Do you think devs are after the Safari functionality or the Safari look-and-feel?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:44): I think it would probably be better to support <input type="search"> with the relevant WF2 replacement features

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:45): 3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a: If they were offered IE-native, Fx-native, Op-native look-and-feel would they take it? Or would they continue to try to craft out the Safari look?

3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:45): well, one of the things Google mentioned was that they feel Safari's rounded corners would be inappropriate on Windows, so they'd like to come up with a different appearance
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:46): http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-ui/ and http://www.w3.org/TR/css3-background/ are two other drafts that seem relevant here.

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:46): 3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a: Oh I suspect browser makers would make the interface look native; I'm more thinking about what site designers are trying to do.

3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:48): no, I think web designers aren't too picky about the appearance, although obviously I'd expect Apple to continue making the search box on www.apple.com look the way it does today
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:49): hmm, less certain of either :)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:49): I suspect the search box on www.apple.com will track Apple UI changes generally.

3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:50): personally I love the little magnifying glass icon - it's a bit weird that it's the "results" option that makes it appear, but having a tiny little icon like that, that I don't have to make myself, the appearance of which could be platform-specific, would be great.
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:50): heh, well yeah, that's what I meant ;-)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:51): we already have code to style search boxes with platform-specific look
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:51): we use it in XUL

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:51): I'd tend to agree that being able to distinguish search inputs (I wouldn't want to be more specific than that in terms of conformance) and being able to jump to search inputs (e.g. with a quick key) would be good.
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:52): yeah, Firefox uses it for things like the download window
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:52): seems likely to make the web a lil more usable :)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:53): although it's possible jumping might be better helped with a container for the form as a whole (e.g. in case of search instructions).

3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:56): I recently implemented something where I wanted the functionality to basically work like searching in iTunes - it filters the results with each keypress.  I had to experiment with using onkeypress, onkeydown, onkeyup, see what worked and what didn't
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (01:59): I wound up using setTimeout with a 50ms delay, to make sure the value of the textbox would have changed by the time my function was called...
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (02:00): and added code to that function to copy the value to a variable, after checking to see if it was different, to avoid repeatedly searching for the same string
3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (02:01): anyway, it just felt like I was reinventing the wheel, and probably poorly.

3e49d4426c0b776106a241ca6729ba2a (02:12): also, in my case, I want the little magnifying glass icon to indicate the purpose of the box, because I don't want to take the space to add a label, and using a placeholder isn't appropriate because I automatically focus on page load (so the user can immediately start typing to filter search results).
